title: [no title]
content: Hi Neko Hibiki,  If you are unable to remove the bean by coughing I would recommend that you see your doctor for an examination.  If large pieces of organic matter stay in the airway they can cause inflammation and give areas for pneumonias to start.  In cases where nothing else is successful, occasionally the physicians will need to use a small camera with a gripping tool to go in and remove the object.  This is done under sedation so it isn't too traumatic.  Best wishes.

title: Echocardiogram
content: Hi,  My husband has been having CT scans twice a year for the past seven years since being diagnosed with MCL. He had chemo, Rituxan and radiation therapy and has been in remission for seven years. An EKG after chemo showed he had experienced a heart attack which we were not aware of. He had surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurism three years ago, a shoulder replacement and has high blood pressure which he has been on medication for and in control for years. He also has sleep apnea and used a CPAP His last CT scan this past July showed an enlarged heart for the first time and it was recommended he have an echocardiogram. He is 65 years old. The interpretation is as follows: 1.  mitral valve shows minimal regurgitation 2.  aortic valve has 3 cusps, is not stenotic, there is      mild to moderate regurgitation 3.  the left ventricle is dilated, there is no regional wall      wall abnormallity, the ejection fraction appears      normal, there is hyperotrophy 4.  the tricuspid valve shows mild regurgitation 5.  there is biatrial enlargement 6.  the right ventricular systolic pressure is estimated      to be 20 mmHg plus the right atrial pressure We were told these results all look okay and there is no recommended follow-up. We do not have a cardiologist in the area to interpret the results. Do these indeed fall in the normal range or should we be going elsewhere for an opinion.                       Thank you, Joe's wife
posted_time: Post  by Joe's wife » Tue Aug 07, 2007 8:01 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - The results, while not textbook  perfect, do seem, in and of themselves, pretty innocuous. The reports generated by technicians and doctors can be terribly intimidating and almost all of them sound ominous when read by a layperson. However, there is nothing in there that would of itself set off any alarms. There are some things which probably bear prudent follow-up in a year or two and thereafter, but nothing that sounds grossly abnormal (the tricuspic aortic valve duly noted).   Regarding what may have been a "silent" myocardial infarction, not only do these events sometimes take place during a vigorous course of chemotherapy, but they can also show up only to normalize later (whereas a true heart attack will leave permanent changes in the EKG and echocardiogram). If one did take place it seems not to have caused any major damage.   Hopefully Joe is doing well on all fronts and it would seem the echocardiogram allows one less thing to worry about. Good luck to you both.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi sbRN - Since each echocardiogram must be evaluated in light of the patient's age, sex, BMI, etc.,  there is a great deal of latitude depending on your doctor's estimation of how your results match up with your physiognomy. However, nothing in the report jumps out at me. Your symptoms sound as though they may well be due to something not directly related to your heart, but which affects the heart. You might be subject to dysautonomia or your could simply be sympathomimetic, especially if you are petite or thin.   The symptoms should be followed by a GP at least, since  the cardiologist seems to have exhausted the  limited avenues available  re: your heart.   I wish I could give you a more specific response, but the sort of symptoms you describe can be attributable to so many different causes, most of them benign, and the echo results seem unremarkable.The history of self-corrected VSD suggests perhaps some mild electrical derangement or perhaps simply an adaptive response which causes some discomfort. If the symptoms are terribly bothersome or actually limit your ability to function then I would suggest persuing them, but it seems not  to be a directly cardiac-related problem based on the little evidence here.   Best of luck to you.

author: armyjoe  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Tue Aug 07, 2007 6:54 pm
title: Rheumatic Fever and Mitral Valve Disorders
content: Hi, I'm 18 year old male and I recently had strep throat in April of 2007. It's now August and I've been having heart palpitations, fatigue, and frequent urination. I was treated for the strep throat with antibioditcs in April, however I didn't go to the doctor for about 2 weeks when the sore throat wasn't going away. I searched my symptoms and found that rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease may be the cause. Most of the information said that rheumatic fever was rare because of antibiodtics, however it seems my symptoms are very similar. I am an active runner and I have been noticing a reduction in my stamina also, is mitral stenosis possibility?
posted_time: Post  by armyjoe » Tue Aug 07, 2007 7:04 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi armyjoe - While it's statistically unlikely that you've developed rheumatic fever, the symptoms you describe warrant at least a checkup by your family physician. While subacute endocarditis (SBE) used to be a common sequel to rheumatic fever, valvular damage was still relatively rare. It can happen, though. It would be wise to rule out any lingering effects of the original bout of RF. Even if it is still active a course of antibiotics would be likely to reduce if not completely avoid any significant damage.   Please do follow this up and also please keep us updated. You're likely in the clear, but there could easily be something else going on that needs addressing. Good luck to you!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Thank you for your question.  Since there are literally hundreds of possible causes for chest pain it would be impossible to diagnose this without exam and testing.  So, the real question becomes how to get the health care you need for the necessary testing and care.  I must stress that getting this evaluation is extremely important. It will either ease your mind considerably or help you through early diagnosis.  It could be something annoying but harmless, or it could be a warning sign.    I'm glad to know you have successfully cut down on the smoking.  As you know, this habit carries great risk factors.  Even someone who has smoked for years can benefit by quitting.  But, this fact does put you at a higher risk for such things as emphysema and cancer.    I wonder if you could locate a cancer screening clinic.  Sometimes communities or hospitals sponsor such events where basic screening can be done at minimal cost.  You might try contacting your local health department and asking for their cancer control people who would know of such resources. It is their job to make a difference in the health of the community and chronic diseases like asthma, heart disease, stroke cancer and even smoking cessation are usually part of their efforts.  This might be a place to start.  Explain your situation and financial constraints so they can help you locate the best available program for you.    If this doesn't help you, at least schedule an exam.  You might also inquire about community health clinics that may offer a sliding fee schedule based on income or at least discounts for cash payment for the uninsured.  Private physicians also sometimes work with people like yourself to find affordable ways to get care.  Most hospitals have charity care programs where you apply for financial assistance (this might be helpful if you must have an expensive diagnostic test at the hospital).  But, the place to start is with the doctor - exam or screening - so you would know what additional testing might be needed.  Good luck.  I know this is a very frustrating situation.    I would also encourage you to make every effort to stop smoking completely.  Again, there are community resources to help with this and it would be the best investment you could make to your health.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Alphacon,  It is possible that your hip pain is actually referred pain from your testes.  If your testicle or epididymis becomes inflamed it can cause the hip and groin/inside thigh area to hurt.    If your epididymis is inflamed it may be due to infection, repeated trauma (such as pressure from tight clothing, etc.) or a blockage in the draining ducts.  I would recommend you follow up with your urologist for a re-evaluation.  If your urologist agrees, it may be worth a trial of antibiotics to see if there is an infection lingering.  Best wishes.

content: Hi.  I'm 36 years old. I have three children. I am overweight at 173 pounds and 5'4". I was diagnosed with MVP when I was pregnant with my second child (13 years ago) after having a lot of palpitations. Let me start by saying that my doctor does not believe that MVP produces any symptoms and everytime I ask a question about it he dismisses me. I do, however, believe that from time to time I experience symptoms. They are text book, sometimes chest pain, fatigue and an occassional panic attack. My last echo (4 years ago)showed no prolapse, but when I went in this week for a virus, the nurse practioner said "wow I can really hear your mvp". Now  for my question(s). Two weeks ago after my cousin's wedding and much dancing my chest hurt a little. Later that night I got quite dizzy feeling like I might pass out. I chalked it up to overdoing it and having a drink or two. I have felt extremely tired over the past two weeks. This past Sunday I was outside for a very short period of time, about 5 minutes (very hot here in FL) and when I came inside I had the same feeling, my chest pounding and thought I might pass out. I laid down and slept for about an hour and woke up without the dizziness but still felt unbelievably tired. The next day I thought I felt better and went to work. Twice within the first hour of being there I had to sit down because I thought I would pass out. I went to the Dr that afternoon. They found that I had a temp of 100.1 and ketones and something else(whiteblood cells abnormal I think) in my urine. Because of all of my symptoms they took my BP standing, sitting and lying down, all normal. They also did an EKG which looked good. They thought I was having a bad UTI because of the test strip and that I'm having frequent urination.The gave me a Rx for Cipro. I went for labs that came back normal except that my fasting sugar was 102. My urine culture also came back normal. So they told me to stop the Rx. So now I'm left with that I'm exhausted, still having chest tightness/heaviness and I'm wondering what to do next or if this a virus that is exaggerating my MVP symptoms. I'm also wondering if I should be worried about the ketones and my sugar levels. I was gestational diabetetic. I'm supposed to go back to the Dr next Wed. for a second follow up and was wondering what questions I should ask or tests I should ask for. I don't think that I'm having a heart attack, but I'm a little worried that there might be something else wrong with my heart causing the chest pains and dizziness. Thanks if you've read this far. I'm sorry I didn't want to leave anything out.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi Laurie Ann - Unfortunately, for many doctors MVP and more specifically MVP Syndrome remain controversial. While there is an entire clinic at the University of Birmingham Medical Center devoted to this phenomenon, there are still some doctors who "don't believe in it." It's easy to blow it off as it includes such a broad spectrum of often vague symptoms that are difficult to reproduce.   The truth is around 10-15 per cent of the population is estimated to have either MVP without symptoms or MVPS with no discernable MVP. No symptoms, no complaints, no problem! When the situation is reversed, however, the doctor is often the one complaining, because the classic "click murmur" that is often associated with MVP can come and go, and the ability to visualize the prolapse via echocardiogram can also be very inconsistent or even non-existent. The "gold standard" for diagnosis of MVP has always been the triad of click murmur, positive prolapse on echo, and non-specifice T-wave changes on EKG. However, most people simply do not meet this standard, yet they all have remarkably similar complaints, and they do begin to fit an admittedly broad, but fairly predictable pattern. You have described it in your post.  While not life-threatening, MVPS can be infuriating at least, both for patient and doctor.   Your glucose level, while technically above the new arbitrary "high normal" of 100, is really so close to normal that in past times you might have been thought to be hypoglycemic. That's how much the thinking has changed on diabetes. I don't really think that's an issue in this case.  The finding of an increased white count would be consistent with a fever and a bacterial or viral illness. The positive ketones (you didn't quote an exact level, but that doesn't matter for now) would also be consistent with a febrile illness, as fever has a tendency to cause us to dry out. Interestingly, one of the more controversial "folk" approaches to managing MVPS is to drink plenty of fluids. This increases blood volume and presumably keeps one from feeling faint, at least some of the time.   As for pericarditis, you would look for sharp, stabbing chest pain, especially on inspiration, and which might radiate up to one or both shoulder tips. Also sharp chest pain on lying supine and relieved by sitting up. Some fever might accompany this problem sometimes as well, but the "rub" usually heard with pericarditis doesn't resemble the click murmur of MVP. That doesn't mean you absolutely don't have pericarditis, something that can be seen on chest x-ray and/or echocardiogram, but it makes it somewhat less likely. Meanwhile the MVP Syndrome begins to sound more likely. It also often blossoms during a stressful period, an illness or, you guessed it, pregnancy.   Following up on the glucose levels and gestational diabetes is a prudent thing to do, but I think it likely you will find everything in order there. Even if that's not the case, your complaints still sound most like someone with MVPS. If it persists and becomes very difficult to cope with, the treatment of choice is one of the beta blockers.  I hope this is helpful to you, and please to keep us updated.

title: CHEST PAIN for the past 9 months
content: Hi I'm a 32 yr old male, ex-smoker (smoked 10-15 a day for the last 12 years).  My cholesterol is 5.2.. no family history of heart problems.. anyway my problem started last August, i felt a sharp pain in my chest and got very worked up about it and this made my heart beat go very fast which worried me more, so i called 999 and was taken to the local A&E, there they did some bloods, xray, BP, and ECG and told me that my heart is fine and it was just chest wall pain, the dr said it could be costochondritis.  MY visits to the A&E continued over the following months.. all in all i must have had 20 visits and 20 ECG's for this pain.  Also had a d-dimer test whic camre back positive so had to have a VQ scan to see if i had PE, fortunately it was not the case.  Anyway in January tis year i had an ECHO done and the cardiologist said its fine, he then booked me for a treadmill test which i had last month, i got the results for this last week and the cardiologist told me that its one of the best excercise tests he's seen in his life, he said i have close to zero chance of hav ing heart disease and that my pain is chest wall pain and that me worrying about it all the time makes it worse.  He told me to get my life back to normal and get myself back to work (i have been off sick from work since this started).     He said he will arrange for an endoscopy in case its something to do with my stomach, but he says its DEFINATELY not my heart thats causing the pain.  I'm sat here typing and i have the pain across my chest, its like a dull ache, also got it across my back, if i press on muscle on my chest it feels sore,  i have been using diclofenac gel on my chest but doesn't really do alot.  My question is, what do you think? The tests that i have had, are they enough to say that i'm not at risk?  I really need to know so that i can get myself back to work next week. I'm on 10mg propranolol everyday to keep my heart rate down because i get palpitations because of the anxiety.  (these can't cause me any harm can they? my heart rate drops down to 40-50bpm at resting rate, is this safe?)  Thanks in advance  Shazad Mokhtar

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Shazad Mokhtar, It certainly sounds like you have had a very thorough workup that seems to have ruled out cardiac problems as the source of your pain and discomfort.  In diagnostic decision trees, we typically consider several options when it comes to chest pain. Cardiac is the first one we consider because of the potential for high threat to life with a cardiac problem. Gastric problems can cause chest pain, as well as pulmonary ones.  You mention that you are experiencing anxiety.  Are you on any medication to help you control the anxiety?  Believe it or not, anxiety can also cause chest pain symptoms.  You did not mention what kind of lifestyle you have, or what kind of work you do.  The fact that the pain is reproducible (meaning that when you touch the chest it feels sore) may indicate muscle pain or strain.  It sounds like your heart tests are normal, thankfully!  Please talk to your primary care physician about your anxiety.  There are several medicines available to help you feel more in control.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Shazad,  A couple things come to mind after reading your feedback.   If the fast heart rate you are experiencing is related to stress/anxiety, then  1.   You may consider exploring with a clinical psychologist, or a mental health support clinic in your area the triggers for your underlying anxiety.   On the surface, it seems like perhaps in your recent past you had an onset of a disturbance to your equilibrium that is now easily fed by stressful issues in your life, causing a flight or fight syndrome in your body.  The best way to tackle and eliminate (hopefully) the reaction is to eliminate the cause. 2.  If the Betablocker (which you had mentioned in your first post was Rx for your rapid heart rate) is not sufficient to control your anxiety, your primary care physician may wish to consider other anxiolytics to replace or supplement the current therapy.  If the heart rate you describe is now simply your body responding to the return to physical activity after a hiatus, then recognize that you may wish to start your routine a little less rigorously, and build up stamina and endurance.   In either event, if the cardiological workup was negative, and you passed your stress test with flying colors, then try to trust them for their expertise and attempt to put your fears to rest about your heart.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Shazad, First of all yes, you are entitled to a copy of your test results.  I would like to caution you however, with your deep concerns about your heart health,  it might be wise to hold off getting those results in your hands until/unless you have another healthcare professional who is requesting to see them.  The verbiage in the test results narrative may open up more of a can of worms for you and feed your anxiety with more undefined/obscure terminology. If you believe, however,  that seeing the test results for yourself may alleviate your fears, then I recommend you ask the cardiologist who read them to sit down with you when you pick up a copy and go over it point by point.    It sounds like somewhere in your life experiences some shocking possibilities came to your mind about heart problems that has lit a fire of fear.  If some near 20 plus tests have cleared you of any definite heart problems, then it seems safe to pick up your life and go on, and not let the fear of possibilities hold you back. Secondly, yes a heart rate of 60 is fine. But if the intended purpose of the Inderal is to help your anxiety, somehow it has failed in that task, and it may be of value if you are needing medicinal support to explore other anxiolytics in its place.   I applaud you for setting an appointment to explore mental health options!

author: shaz29  Guest Posts: 24 Joined: Mon Apr 23, 2007 3:13 pm
title: [no title]
content: hi I recently saw a cardiologist, the following is what he has written.. is there anything to be concerned about?     "He has had very persistent and sharp left sided chest pains of sudden onset, seldom persisting for more than several minutes and fairly typical of inter costal neuralgia, with duller chest wall discomfort and tenderness persisting once the sharp pain is relieved. He has lost weight but stopped training, in fact stopped working and has at times been somewhat bed bound so this has had a major impact.     I understand that he has had a recent VQ scan and CXR and that these were allegedly normal so underlying rarities such as chest wall tumours which crop up occasionally seem reassuringly unlikely. He seems very concerned and pre-occupied about havig heart problems so I have given him a thorough cardiac MOT. This may have been exacerbated by the finding on ECG of left axis deviation, probably in association with partial right bundle branch block, these are ECG changes seen in association of atrial septal defect and cardiac ultrasound today reassuringly has excluded this remote possibility which I any case would be painless. We do occasionally see somewhat bright pericardial shadows posteriorly and he has shown this to some extent although I do not think his pains are likely to be due to pericarditis but they have been present virtually on a daily basis without remission.     He also is tall ad slim habitus but has neither features of either skin or joint hyperextensibility nor features of Marfan's syndrome and his aortic root appears to be normal on ultrasound. I think he can be reassured about his heart and given his concern and the impact this has had on his life. I am arranging for a reassuring excercise ECG and shall then encourage him to re-start training. I think he can discontinue pain killers and anti-inflammatories but in the very short term I would be interested to see whether Flecainide 50mg bd has any impact although this may be too small a dose to impact on neuralgic pain, with the intension of continuing this only in the short term and if there is clear improvement in his symptoms.     I shall re-assess in 2 months if his symptoms are worsening and the weight loss persists then I would consider a chest CT scan, hopefully he will get his life back to normal and return to work in the near future.     My provisional diagnosis is that is most likely to be inter costal neuralgic pain. Incidentally he is seeing a physiotherapist and I think deep breathing and general return to fitness and improved posture may also be of benefit"     The above is what he wrote after seeing me in january... just wanted to know whether I should worry about the pericarditis that he mentioned or whether there is anything else I should be concerned about?     Thanks in advance     Shazad

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Shazad, Your cardiologist has beenvery thorough to investigate all potential cardiac related caused of your chest pain. He mentions the possibility of putting you on Flecainide.  This medication is a class IC antiarrhythmic that has had some success in improving myotonia. Myotonia is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by the slow relaxation of the muscles after voluntary contraction or electrical stimulation. I suggest that you ask your MD for further information about the use and risk of Flecainide for you.  It does seem unlikely that you have any substantiated concerns about your heart. You may have the intercostal neuralgia that was mentioned, and it may be of value to pursue that thinking at this point, and find a way to get back into your usual patterns of life. Have you considered consulting a neurologist? This specialist may have other ideas that may help you.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Jan, Stress can certainly contribute to the feeling of pounding with your heartbeat.  Caffeine can also play a role in this - both in the form of coffee and tea, and also in regular caffeinated sodas.  If I were able to triage your symptoms on a face to face basis, I would like to know what your blood pressure and heart rate is at the time you feel the pounding.  The fact that you feel better when you wake up could refer to the fact that you are better rested, or that the offending culprit (soda, tea, coffee) is now out of your system.  Please do talk with your primary care physician if the symptoms do not get better, or go to your local urgent care center.  I appreciate that you are "listening" to your body, and recognize that there are some "not normals" that need to be addressed.

author: susieQ1  Guest Posts: 45 Joined: Thu Mar 01, 2007 3:57 pm
title: cardiocolic reflex
content: I am 63 years & for most of my adult life when I have sharp colon pain, gallbladder pain, childbirth, any pain that won't let up I get nauseous & then faint.  I have asked dr's for many years what is causing this & no  answer until now. I just recently read of cardiocolic reflex but not much info.  Is this dangerous? Is it treatable?   What type physician should I see?  Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by susieQ1 » Thu Mar 01, 2007 4:11 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I am not familiar with the term cardiocolic reflex; however, there are many "reflexes" or cardiac responses that exist.  The most common is often referred to as a vasovagal reflex.  In this case, stimulation of the vagal nerve by many means can cause the heart to slow down resulting in lightheaded feelings and occasionally fainting.  There is another condition known as neurocardiogenic syncope that is not completely understood yet.  It is thought that there are some primative nerve fibers in the heart that sense when the heart is beating too fast.  When this happens they slow the heart down.  In some people a normal increase in heart rate, as would occur with standing to compensate for the drop in blood pressure until the blood vessels can respond, triggers these fibers to react.  They they react over vigorously slowing the heart down when it should be speeding up.  This leads to a drop in blood pressure, lightheadness and sometimes fainting.  It is possible that, in some people, pain or other stimulation may raise the heart rate rapidly enough to cause a similar triggering of these fibers leading to transient underperfusion.  This could cause nausea and lightheadedness and even fainting.  This is not particularly dangerous.  When it happens, the best thing to do is lie down for a moment.  This helps ease the work of blood flow around the body and will help the symptoms resolved.  Even if one faints from this it is not particularly dangerous other than the possibility of injury from falling, etc.  To help prevent this it is important to stay very well hydrated.  If you continue to have frequent symptoms you can talk with your regular doctor about other treatments.  Hope this helps.

title: Mitral Valve Prolapse? doctors giving the run around
content: Hi, I am writing for my boyfriend who is 20 years old. He has been having symptoms that we thought were heart attack symptoms. He has been to the emergency room three times, all of which his EKG's have come back normal, and all the doctors dismiss him saying, "you're too young to be having heart problems." Today he had an appointment with his primary care physician who refused to even listen or give him a stress test with an echo. The doctor had his mind made up that it was in his head before he even got to tell him what was going on. His symptoms are mostly brought on or worsened by exercise, caffeine, smoking marijuana (which he has quit in the last couple weeks). The doctors have tried to say he is having the pain because of quitting, even though the pain is why he quit. He has almost every symptom of MVP, and he had Pectis Excavatum which was corrected when he was 13. Two years ago, he had a follow up surgery because one of his ribs overgrew into bone where it should have been cartilage, and broke while he was exercising. His mother has lupus, has father was prediabetic. I am not sure if either of those could have an effect on the situation. I was also wondering if it is possible to have MVP without having an audible click or murmur. Please help us, we have been getting the run around and no one seems to think he is credible.
posted_time: Post  by tigrepanthera » Fri Dec 29, 2006 8:50 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Mitral valve prolapse is an extremely common issue, especially in women.  It essentially is when the mitral valve comes to a close, then buckles backwards a little.  This produces the classically described mid-systolic click.  Most people with MVP will have no symptoms and likely will go their whole life without knowing it.  Generally no treatment is needed and antibiotics are not required before dentist visits, etc.  Occasionally MVP will be associated with a small leak in the valve, known as mitral valve insufficiency or mitral valve regurgitation.  Depending on how severe the leak is, this, too, may be assymptomatic or may have some symptoms.  When MVP is symptomatic, symptoms can include chest pain (possibly due to stretching of the attaching bands, known as chordae tendonae), palpitations, nervous feelings/panic attacks, fatigue, and difficulty breathing with exercise.  If you are able to describe your boyfriend's pain, we may be able to comment more on possible causes.  While the statement about his age is generally true - 20 year olds generally do not have heart problems - this does not mean that they cannot exist.    Unfortunately, many other things can mimic pain that comes from the heart.  I would encourage your boyfriend to continue to follow up with his doctor and discuss his symptoms.  Hope this helps.

content: Many of his symptoms do go along with cardiac type pain, some not as commonly.  I would say that this is definitely worth looking into regarding his heart. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi rmansfield, Blue fingernails and toenails, and shortness of breath are typical signs of cyanosis with one particular cause being a lack of oxygen. author: xtine  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Feb 09, 2006 6:22 pm
title: Unexplained Chest Pain
content: I am a 31 year old female, non smoker with no family history of heart disease.  I am in good health, not overweight and have not had any major surgeries.  I am also not on any medications.  I have had reoccurring chest pains just to the left of the centre of my chest.  The pain comes and goes with no known reason.  I usually notice the pain after a big meal or when I'm resting in the evening.  This pain has been reoccurring for about 8 months or more.  The pain feels very deep and I cannot feel it when I press my chest.  The pain is like a dull throbbing.  It may last for 30 seconds or a few minutes.  I also occasionally feel pain under my arm or at the bottom of my left rib.  Sometimes my throat feels tight when the pain occurs and sometimes I feel numbness in my arm.  I don't notice any pattern to it and don't necessarily notice it while I'm exerting energy.  I do sometimes notice it when I'm walking or if I move a certain way.  If I try to repeat the way I move, I cannot make the pain come again.  I also noticed the pain today when I was walking outside and breathing in cold air.  My family GP did an ECG and I'm assuming it was normal because I never heard back from her.  She felt the pain was muscular because I could localize the pain as it wasn't spread all across my chest.  I did go to the ER about 3 months ago because I was very worried about the pain and getting anxiety from it.  I had a couple more ECGs, blood tests, Xray and was told everything was normal.  I still worry about this pain because I feel it's getting worse.  I now feel a dull ache in-between my shoulder blades, stiff shoulder, sore left calf, sore left hip joint and sore left arm.  My arm muscles do feel sore and when I press on them I do feel muscle pain.  I went to my Chiropractor and she did a thermal scan which scanned my nerves and joints.  She says that the pain is most likely muscle but if it makes me feel better I should check with my GP again.  I've been reading up on angina and read that some form of angina only occurs with rest.  I am not sure if my symptoms are similar to this.  I know that I am young and that this is probaby not a factor however I am still very anxious about this.  I am wondering where I should go from here- I'd like to see my GP and order some tests.  I am wondering what tests to order i.e.. stress test and heart monitor?  And will I be able to get good peace of mind if the results come back normal.  I am not confident with just an ECG test.  I am also wondering how this could be muscular pain?  The pain is very deep, right near my heart and doesn't seem to come and go with stretching, lifting etc.  Can heart pain result in muscle pain of these other areas? Or is the fact that my arm muscle, calf and shoulder sore a good sign that the chest pain is muscular too?  This pain occurs almost nightly now and I'm just concerned that if it's heart related then it's getting worse.  Lately, I've been feeling that my heart beat sometimes beats fast.  I am hoping that this is just stress or anxiety and that once I get checked out I'll be proven wrong.  I should also mention that I am a Stay at Home Mom who looks after a 24lb toddler.  If it is muscle pain I'm assuming it's from lifting him.  However, I am right handed and the pain is only ever on my left side.  My Chiroparactor also feels that my posture at the computer could be aggrivating this.  I am trying to avoid sitting at the computer to see if it gets better.  Thank You for your time, Christine

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear xtine,  The chest contains many organs, like the heart, lungs with its pleural covering, esophagus, muscles, ribs, tendons, and nerves.   It is more likely that the pain you feel is of muscle origin.  Overexertion of the chest wall muscles (spasm) or their inflammation as a part of viral infection like flu or cold results also in Chest pain, the pain is usually aggravated with certain moves posture, and is usually associated with tenderness over the affected muscles. Pain due to rib or chest wall bone disease is also another cause of Chest pain.   Muscle spasm is a body reaction to injury in tissues Causes of muscle injury include: Muscle fatigue  Heavy exercise  Maintained wrong postures  Self care and avoiding the precipitating cause will lead to a gradual but clear improvement in the pain. Home treatment includes the use of analgesics, cold or hot therapy. Rest for maximum two days is also beneficial  Cardiac causes, should be excluded in any case of chest pain as your doctor did. Other tests to exclude cardiac causes include Stress ECG, cardiac catheter and Echocardiography.  Sometimes Chest pain is not originating from the chest itself; instead it is due to problems in the digestive tract. These problems include IBS, Gastritis,  these medical problems are usually related to meals and are not related to deep breath or physical exercises.  I advise you to follow up with your doctor. Only by complete history and physical examination, the correct diagnosis can be reached.   Keep us updated. Best regards,

author: mtstanley  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Nov 18, 2006 8:17 am
title: chest pain
content: Xtine: I will second Dr. Mahmouds comments.  The most important thing you did was to have this checked.  I would much rather see a patient come in for no (life threatening) reason and get peace of mind than sit at home and deteriorate or die.  Lets talk about this.  1- You did have an exam with GP.  You had an ECG, and I assume that it is normal because your doctor did not call you, but you shouldn't. Since this concerns you,ask.  Maybe he or she forgot.  It never hurts to sleep a little better.  2- You had a cardiac workup at ER, including xray, blood work (which looks for specific cardiac enzymes that elevate if the heart muscle is damaged)  I am sure that you had a 12 lead ECG and the other ECG was probably and echocardiogram.  All normal.  (that is good).  3- As Dr. Mahmoud stated, there are many things that could cause this.  One that you might consider, after talking to your GP is to get some lidocaine and maalox.  WHen this occurs, drink it.  If the pain goes away, then you know its related to the stomach, esophogus, etc.  That would be a clue.  It should go away almost immediately with the lidocaine.  3- You notice this pain when you lie down or eat a meal.  This sounds to me like a hiatal hernia.  This is in the area of the diaphram and can be very frustrating.  I'm sure you can read up online and ask your doctor to examine you for that.    It doesn't sound like anything you have going on is life threatening.  I hope this is helpful to you.  MSTANLEY, MD, FACOS,AAOS

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi  You are allowed all kinds of aerobic exercises like walking, cycling, swimming etc, upto your symptom threshold. As you go on doing these, your symptom threshold should go up gradually.  Check your CO2 levels frequently. Retained CO2 in your type of case can make you drowsy.  Slightly enlarged heart can go back to normal with mild diuretic therapy.  Mild tricuspid regurge is a normal finding in up to 40 % of general population. In your case you could be having more than mild TR, due to your chronic Asthma. In general, chronic Asthma patients usually develop RIGHT heart enlargement, not the left. Please check on that.   Apurva

author: asdf  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Sun Sep 18, 2005 6:51 pm Location: asdf
title: re: Echo results of 3 valves
content: You will probably see many posts regarding trivial/mild valve regurgitation throughout this forum.   The same rule applies:   If the 2d echo didn't show any valve abnormalities-- there is probably nothing to worry about.     Mild/trivial regurgitation is a normal finding in upwards of 40% (probably higher) of normal population studies.   The only one that would be worrysome is mild aortic (but trace aortic not so much).     Mitral valve prolapse is a pretty benign condition-- so even with trivial mitral regurgitation, it is just a normal variation with a normal person.    Yes, the echos are very sensitive and can easily pick this up.

author: solis  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Feb 22, 2006 9:45 pm
title: Pregnancy and Mitral Valve Reguritation
content: Hello, I am a 31yr old woman with mitral valve prolapse and severe mitral valve reguritation. I have known that I have had  this condition for about 4 years. My symptoms are fatigue, palpitations, lowered excerise tolerance. rMy cardiologist watches me closely (I have at least 1 echo and 1 stress test a year). I am active with excercise and relatively healthy otherwise. He has made me aware that the valve is bad enough that I do need to have surgery to most likely repair the valve (and hopefully not replace it). As far as the surgery goes, we are just waiting it out and watching how the condition progresses. I am recently married and want to start a family. This will be the first child for me and my husband. My doctor has some reservations about having the surgery before I get pregnant because of the chance of having to replace the valve instead of repair it and therfore having to take blood thinners for the reat of my life which will greatly affect my chances of becomeing pregnant. I had a TEE and the results were that everything looks fine for now. Should I listen to his advice and hold off on the surgery or should I get a second opinion? I know wheather or not to have the surgery goes on  a case by case basis but I am not sure if pregnancy will be tolerated well with this conditions and my symptoms. Is there  much literature on pregnancy and mitral vavle reguritation?
posted_time: Post  by solis » Thu Feb 23, 2006 11:32 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Pregnancy and mitral valve reguritation
content: Dear Solis,  Pregnancy and delivery both pose a very stressful situation to the cardiovascular system.  The peak stress is around the 26-28th weeks of pregnancy and immediately after delivery of baby and placenta during delivery.  If you plan on starting a family prior to having your mitral valve repaired or replaced, you will have to have an obstetrician who is specialized in high-risk pragnancies and you will have to be followed up by your cardiologist very diligently and you have to be really committed to follow-up appointments.  If you need to have your valve replaced, at this stage in your life, you might want to consider talking to your doctor about a biosynthetic valve or tissue valve. They only require that you be started on blood thinners for 6 months and then you won't need to take any blood thinners. Their draw back is that they don't last as long as the artificial or mechanical valves and they will need to be replaced sooner than a mechanical valve, and as mentioned before no need for blood thinners which is a great advantage for women of child bearing age.  This is one of the most difficult decisions that a doctor and his patient have to make. If your doctor thinks it is better for you to have your valve repaired before your pregnancy, i would say go for it. If he thinks that you can go through pregnancy without having the valve repaired, i will remind you once again that you have to be really diligent about who your obstetrician will be, where you are going to have your delivery and all of your follow-up appointments.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Alice  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Feb 14, 2005 10:36 am
title: Exercise-Induced Pulmonary Hypertension
content: Thank you for taking my question, and those that you have previously taken.  I was diagnosed at a PH clinic (a long way from my home) in mid-2005 with Exercise-Induced PH. This diagnosis was made by exercise stress test with an IV contrast agent, on a supine bike. I also did 6-minute walk achieving 1580 feet. My PH was described as being caused by my high blood pressure being inadequately controlled.   Since then I have been taking diltiazem 120mg, lipitor 10mg, lisinopril 25mg and half a triamterene/hctz 37.5/25 per day (this last med, introduced Dec 05), brought down my BP to normal.). Taking a whole diuretic tablet left me short of breath, hence the half. I am 60, slim, F, non-smoker.   Recently, as a yearly follow up, I had an echocardiogram at my local hospital and this was described as being not significantly different from one I had done at the same hospital just over a year ago. One note, however, was, 'Normal right ventricle with moderate tricuspid regurgitation and significantly elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 65 mmHg. Normal pulmonic valve.' This was an increase from 58 mmHg.  What I am wondering is whether the pressure is normal for my age, and whether I should consider the pressure obtained at the PH clinic as the correct one. Estimated pressure then was 32mgHg with BP 158/90, which increased to 60mgHg with BP 184/82 at peak exercise.   I continue to become more SOB, don't feel like doing much most of the time, occasionally have a sensation of nausea or lightheadedness, no appetite.  I am at a loss to understand it, only to know that my quality of life has decreased. Maybe this is all to do with my age and I should accept this.  Alice
posted_time: Post  by Alice » Thu Apr 06, 2006 11:44 am

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  The cut off level for diagnosis of Pulmonary hypertension has been raised to 45 mm Hg from earstwhile 25 mm Hg because mild functional tricuspid regurgitation, from which the PH is measured, is a normal and common entity in general population.  In view of this at 65 mm Hg you have only mild PH. This should not be the cause of SOB.  You must rule out other causes of SOB like chronic bronchitis, Asthma, LV dysfunction, coronary heart disease and anemia.   Dr. A. Madia
posted_time: Post  by Dr. A. Madia » Wed Apr 12, 2006 12:47 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Exercise-Induced Pulmonary Hypertension
content: Dear Alice,  The ultimate test for pulmonary hypertension is having something called a right sided heart catheterization where a catheter is introduced through one of the big veins to the right side of the heart and will be used to measure the actual pressure inside the right heart chambers and the pulmonary arteries. It is also used in certain cases to give medications to see whether or not the pulmonary pressure drops.  In addition to the disease entities that Dr. Madia mentioned need to be ruled out such as bronchitis (where you have to have a lung function test done), there are others that need to be ruled out as well as work-up for pulmonary hypertension to see whether or not pulmonary hypertension is caused by these diseases. The most notorious ones are obstructive sleep apnea (so you have to have a sleep study done) and chronic blood clots to the lung (a condition known as chronic pulmonary thrombo-embolism) so a ventilation perfusion scan needs also to be done. Other blood tests need to be done to rule out inflammation of the blood vessels known as vasculitis as well.  If all of these tests come back negative, then you have pulmonary hypertension of unknown etiology, a condition known as primary pulmonary hypertension.  From your history, i assume that you are following with a cardiologist, if you are not, i strongly urge you to, seeing a lung doctor also, is not a bad idea just to make sure that you don't have a lung problem that is causing the pulmonary hypertension.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Pootiegirl  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Jan 25, 2006 10:36 pm Location: Maine
title: New diagnosis of MVP
content: My 20 year old daughter was just discharged from the hospital today. Initial diagnosis in E.R. was bradycardia (sinus, with resting rates in the 30's) and hypokalemia (level was 3.3). Initial symptoms that sent her to the E.R. were s.o.b., palpatations, weakness, tremors, extreme anxiety, chest tightness, hot flashes, pre-syncope. She had no pre-existing condi tions and took no medications. She was hydrated with IV fluids and potassium was replaced. No improvement in HR. She was admitted for observation. Although she did not have a sore throat, swollen glands, fever, or unusual CBC results, she had a positive result for a monospot. Also a cardiac echo showed she has a small mitral prolapse. This would explain most of those symptoms, but I wonder about the bradycardia and the hypokalemia. Can these be part of the MVP also? By the way, I have a trace mitral regurg myself. Thanks for your help.
posted_time: Post  by Pootiegirl » Wed Jan 25, 2006 11:33 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Pootiegirl, Typical symptoms of MVP are generally speaking, dizziness, shortness of breath, palpitations or arrhythmias, fatigue, chest pain unassociated to cardiac disease, etc. Unless the prolapse progresses, typically there is no required treatment. When this condition worsens medication regimens are generally attempted to decrease symptoms prior to any other intervention. Mildly low potassium levels may be diet related, decreased in certain medications, etc. A heart rate in the 30's is quite low but in my opinion I would not likely associate either the mildly low potassium level nor the decreased heart rate with a slight MVP. Has she been referred to a Cardiologist? If she has not, I would suggest an inquiry about doing so. If no known cardiac abnormalities are found, then there should be an evaluation for any metabolic or endocrine disorders. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN
posted_time: Post  by Theresa Jones, RN » Thu Jan 26, 2006 6:49 am

author: PACU*RN  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Sun Jan 29, 2006 4:46 pm Location: Denver, CO
title: [no title]
content: It is quite unusual for a healthy 20 year old w/ a small MVP to present with a symptomatic bradycardia in the 30's and hypokalemia.  You stated that she has no preexisting conditions which indicates that this episode was the first of its kind for her.  If she had an endocrine or cardiac abnormality it likely would have shown itself before now, which leads me to suspect that possibly an ingested subtance (drug) may have brought this about.  A 24-48 hour holter monitor could be performed to evaluate her heart rhythm but would most likely be normal on this 20 year old.    Karen Marshall RN

author: itsmethere  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Tue Jan 31, 2006 9:29 pm Location: NYC and MA
title: Desperate for diagnosis
content: I am a 21 year old female and I have been having my symptoms since age 9.  I have been having really severe and debilitating shortness of breath combined with chest pain, fatigue and even diziness (when my symptoms are at their peak) for all these years.  My limbs also get cold and I begin to urinate more frequently.  These symptoms last for days at a time and vary in intensity throughout their span.  They are so bad that I am scared of dying. They seem to be coming from the heart. I have had some periods where I am constantly bothered by my symptoms and then periods when I am symptom free for three months at a time.  Between age 15 and 17 my symptoms seemed to have receded but then reappeared again.  Ages 12-14 were particularly bad and so have been the past three years.  I had even lost my first-year of college because I was feeling so bad and was scared of dying.  I was so scared that I did not tell my family about these problems until age 12 at which point I started going to cardiologists.  Over the past nine years, I have seen a total of four cardiologists and had all the standard noninvasive, office-based tests done repetitively multiple times.  I was also seen at an emergency room three times at the time of my symptoms.  The doctors do not find anything that concerns them with my heart.  My EKGs are normal, my echos(standard through the chest wall) show trace mitral and tricuspid valve regurge but they seem to be within the normal range and the doctors are not alarmed.  I also have a small PFO but this is again a normal finding.  My 24 hour monitor showed extra beats but I was also told that this isn't a concern.  My chest x-ray is normal.  Could it be that my echos underestimate the extent of my valve regurge, for instance, and that I do have a heart problem?  I am trully feeling really bad and I do not believe that it's of a psychological origin  (I have tried psych medication) and have always had a strong feeling that something may be wrong with my heart.  Do you have any ideas of what it can be and how I should proceed?  Thanks.

title: WPW
content: My husband is 41 yr. old and was diagnosed with WPW at 30 years of age. Ablation was attempted but not successful because the extra valve was too close to the main artery and would have required a pace maker at such an early age. Doctors hopefully damaged it enough that the tacacardia would not happen as often or not ever again. Over the past 5 years he has what we call episodes. During these he experiences the following:  Agitation, Discomfort (pulling sensation) in the chest (left side) that moves over the shoulder to his back and then makes the left arm feel tingly, He suffers from asthma and that gets aggravated by the episodes. His muscles shake. All of the symptoms start gradually get to a peak and then start to subside. Usually lasting about 1 – 2 hours. Once these symptoms subside he feels like he is have hot flashes and the pressure in his head with a tingling sensation at the top of his head.  We have been to the hospital a number of times and seen a cardiologist. Blood tests have been done to check the plat lets and this comes back normal. They do an EKG and that shows the WPW but they are not concerned. Was told this is normal for someone with his condition. Blood pressure is a little off but gets back to normal after a few hours.  Yesterday at the Urgent Care BP was 141/90 15 min after the symptoms stopped and 45min later it was 134/99, 2 hours after that it was 122/78.   Please note that EVERYTIME we go into the Urgent Care or hospital the symptoms stop before he is ever called in to see a doctor.   My concern is that no one seems to know what is wrong and I am worried that it is the WPW acting up again and it might be time for the pacemaker.  There is no history of heart diease. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: wpw
content: Dear Tic,  Your husband has to go to the hospital immediately once he starts having the symptoms of the episode.  The intermittent and sudden onset nature of the episodes makes some rare conditions jump to mind and they have to be ruled out unless they were already ruled out: 1. Pheochromocytoma (a rare tumour that puts out adrenaline in the blood). 2. Carcinoid syndrome (a rare tumour that puts out serotonin in the blood).  Your husband's symptoms can be also caused by an asthma attack in itself. A panic attack can also cause these symptoms. If you can say for sure that the attacks are associated with your husband using his albuterol inhaler, albuterol can cause fast heart rate and muscle shakes real bad in some people.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Lunula faded and turned blue
content: Dear Randy,  Lunulae turning blue/purplish is usually an indication of either poor circulation or not enough oxygen.  i think with your mom's history of smoking, she could have developed emphysema. Also, smoking can lead to heart disease and poor circulation.  Your mom being obese, she can have a condition called sleep apnea or another one called obesity hypoventilation syndrome and they can cause low oxygen in the blood if very severe.  i know it is not usually that cold in kentucky but cold weather will also make the lunulae bluish  Please, have your mother see her doctor because even though this is a clinical sign of a simple condition yet it can be cause by more severe ones and she needs to be evaluated.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: DavesMom  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Fri Aug 19, 2005 6:53 pm Location: Illinois
title: Fatigue after exercise
content: Hello,   I had my aortic valve replaced and an aneurysm repaired in 1999.  Prior to my AVR I was heavily into aerobics, but since then my exercise routine has consisted of a daily walk lasting between an hour and an hour and half. I don't "power walk," but I don't just plod along either.  I never get out of breath and always cool down.  I've noticed recently that instead of leaving me invigorated, this walk now almost always leaves me fatigued and in need of a nap! I drink a ton of water throughout the day so I don't think it could be dehydration. My worst sin is that I overdo the carbs, but blood glucose tests have always been normal.  It just doesn't make sense, especially since I've been walking for so many years. BP is fine. Last year's echo was fine.  Any opinions on whether or not this could be a sign of a problem with my valve? Guess I'm just a bit paranoid because fatigue was the only symptom I had prior to my valve replacement.    Your thoughts would be appreciated. Thanks in advance.   Cheers!
posted_time: Post  by DavesMom » Fri Jan 27, 2006 6:58 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Fatigue after exercise
content: Dear DavesMom,  What kind of other medical problems do you have if any. Did you have a mechanical valve or a bioprosthetic valve. What are the medications that you are currently taking and whether or not there was any new additions to your medications.  To begin with, if you have a prosthetic valve and you are taking coumadin (a blood thinner), this could be an indication of a low blood count which means that you might be chronically bleeding (especially if you are taking over the counter pain medications like aleve or advil) which might increase the risk of bleeding, so i would recommend to check a blood count.  This could secondary to a general disease, such as an underactive thyroid gland, so i would recommend checking your thyroid functions.  You should have a new echocardiogram to make sure that the valve is functioning properly especially if your symptoms started to develop after your last echocardiogram.  A new medication could be the culprit behind this fatigue.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped and awaiting your response. content: Hi,  Thank you very much for your reply.  To answer your questions, I have a mechanical valve and take coumadin.  I have also been on 400 mgs of Tegretol for several years due to complex partial seizures. (The seizures have been well controlled with the Tegretol.)  The only other medication I take is 10 mg of Lipitor. I am 49 and not overweight.  I just had a lipid panel done last week which showed no problems with kidney, thyroid, blood glucose, etc.  As mentioned, my BP is always good and my heart rate is almost always in the 60s.  Resting heart rate is sometimes between 55-59 beats per minute.  I have an appointment for my yearly echo in a couple of weeks. Last year's was fine so I would hope that the valve hasn't deteriorated in that short of a time - it needs to last me many more years. : )  (I've already been through two heart surgeries - don't want another!) Are there more subtle symptoms of internal bleeding that I should look out for? I have never seen anything abnormal  in my stool or urine.  It's puzzling but maybe I'm just overreacting. Still, it happens too frequently to be just a fluke.  Again, I appreciate your time.  Any other comments would be appreciated.  Cheers!

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Fatigue after exercise
content: Dear DavesMom,  Thank you very much for the update.  Eventhough there is no obvious external bleeding, the bleeding can still be there but it is usually of a small amount and happens over a long period of time so it is subtle and the only symptom that one gets are symptoms of anemia which are fatigue, shortness of breath on exertion, dizzy spells and sometimes blackout spells.  Mechanical valves should last 10-15 years before deteriorating. So, hopefully, your echo will turn out ok.  With the lipitor (and the like medications), there is a chance of muscle damage. Eventhough the muscle damage usually manifests itself with muscle pain. i would not say that checking a muscle enzyme test is unreasonable.  If you have not checked with your doctor, please, do so as soon as possible and i still recommend to check a complete blood count, a thyroid function test, test to check blood in the stools (if your blood count turns out significantly lower than the last time it was checked) and a muscle enzyme test.  Tegretol also can cause fatigue and weakness sometimes, so i would recommend that you have a tegretol level checked to see whether or not the level has been stable.  Thank you very much for using our website http://thedoctorslounge. net and I hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M. D.

author: Bestof96  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Jan 27, 2006 9:42 am Location: SC
title: Heart disease kills everyone in my family
content: I am a 39 year old female, diagnosed with MVP 20 years ago.  Both of my grandfathers died in their mid forties of heart attacks.  My uncle (father's brother) died of a massive heart attack at 41 while out jogging.  My mother (55) has tachycardia and has had angioplasty.  Recently, over the last month, I've developed numerous symptoms.  The first thing I noticed was general swelling that seemed to happen very quickly.  I was unable to wear my rings and certain clothing.  I was also having some mild chest pain, palpitations, left arm pain and pain in the left side of my neck. I was seen at the local emergency room.  EKG was normal, Cardiac enzymes (normal), C-MET Panel (normal), Platelet count slightly elevated, Urinalysis (normal).  The doctor there told me that my liver was swollen, my spleen palpable and I have pitting edema I went to see my family doctor who did an EKG which he said showed some slight abnormalities but nothing serious.  He ordered cardiac enzymes (normal) and an excercise stress test (normal).  He did say that I had a very significant weight gain since my last appt. 3 wks earlier.  But once he ruled out heart attack he seemed very unconcerned about my symptoms.  My blood pressure at this appointment was 126/72.  He diagnosed me with hypertension????? and put me on beta blockers.  I've noticed a substantial decrease in the chest pain while taking this medication but I still don't really know what's wrong.   My other symptoms include exhaustion after minimal effort or excercise, insomnia, weakness, backache, some nausea, tighness in chest, lightheaded, numbness and tingling in hand, forgetfulness, difficulty concentrating,   Could I have a heart problem that these tests didn't indicate?
posted_time: Post  by Bestof96 » Fri Jan 27, 2006 10:34 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Heart disease kills everyone in my family
content: Dear Bestof96,  You definitely have a strong family history of coronary disease given the fact that your mother developed coronary disease before the age of 60.  It is now the time to try and make sure that all of the other risk factors are taken care of.  If you are a smoker, stop smoking immediately. If you have high blood pressure, it has to be vigorously controlled. Make sure you exercise on regular basis and you have your weight at its optimum. Your cholesterol has to be checked if not already done and if it is high it has to be lowered (exercise, diet and medications if needed).  Some of the symptoms that you had could be attributed to mitral valve prolapse especially that the symptoms improved a lot since you were started on beta blockers.  These symptoms can also be caused by a neck spine problem given your symptoms of neck pain and numbness in your hand.  The fatigue and other symptoms of forgetfullness and being unable to concntrate are non-specific and can be caused by a lot of causes.  i am not sure what caused this sudden "significant increase in weight" but i think a cause has to be found. If this was before your period then this understandable especially if you have been gaining weight slowly and then you had this sudden fluid retention prior to your period.  Regarding hypertension, the blood pressure has to be higher than or equal to 140/90 to be classified as hypertension. Previously lower numbers that were not considered hypertension, now are called pre-hypertension as studies have shown that over time even if the blood pressure did not reach 140/90, there was still an increased cardiovascular risk and it was found that these patients are twice more likely to develop hypertension than the patients with lesser values.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: starquake  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Jan 29, 2006 11:09 am Location: NYC
title: Aortic valve stenosis?
content: Hi, I'm a 36 year-old male with a long history of exercise (I was a competitor in a couple of sports until my late 20s), but this was all despite sometimes intense PVCs and chest discomfort.  EKG shows just incomplete RBBB, stress test from a few years ago was good, but this week, the echocardiogram came back indicating "minor" aortic valve stenosis...the tech said the value was "just a bit above 1.0" and that it doesn't get serious until you get to 2.0, and there's no calcification....the valve just doesn't quite open as far as it should.  She made it sound like not a big deal, but for an athlete, I wonder if it makes a difference.  If I'm training intensely but my left ventricle is always working against a mild load, is exercise going to drive me to early decompensation/ventricular hypertrophy? (there's no evidence of it yet...I'm asking a preemptive question); I also wonder if my persistent symptoms of heaviness in the chest at the beginning of exercise may have to do with left ventricular overloading due to the stenosis.  I usually don't feel good for the first 10 minutes of running (various chest discomforts, left shoulderblade pain, etc)...and then sometimes there's kind of like a "kick" in the chest, and the heaviness very suddenly clears and I can breathe easier.  Someitmes, while running, I also get a charp, intense pain behind the sternum, but it passes almost instantly....it's extremely intense (like a knife quickly cutting the sternum from the inside) and frightening however...I'm wondering if aortic innervation may be responding to the distention pressures at the valve roots.    Is there a minimally invasive technique that can adjust (not replace) the aortic valve to open more fully if it's not calcified?  I have a very good grasp of the cardiac anatomy, physiology, and mechanics, and I have a deep biology background, so I'd appreciate a comprehensive answer (you won't confuse me).  Thanks!

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  Aortic stenosis can cause chest pain on exertion. However for that to occur one must have more than moderate stenosis. Here you have not given details. Aortic stenosis is measured in two ways. One is Valve Area. Normal area is obout 4-5 square cm. How much is yours as per the report? Another way is see pressure gradient. Upto about 10 mm Hg  of peak gradient across the aortic valve is normal. Then also upto 50 mm Hg is mild to moderate. You stating 1.0 and 2.0 does not make any sense.   Secondly even if mild AS is there it would not hamper your physical activity. Moderate and severe AS can easily be opened up with Ballon Vavuloplasty thru the skin, no operation necessary.  Slight chest discomfort at the beginning of exercise is common even in normal healthy individuals, I have noticed. Sometimes it has to do with stomach gasses. As the exercise progresses the gas is burped out and all symptoms are gone and the subject can carry on with the rest of the exericse.   Dr. A Madia

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Dear Tightrope, All of your symtoms are due to your mitral prolpase. MVP can cause vague atypical chestpains, tachycardia, fluttering sensations, even dizziness. Your episodes of high BP are due to secondary anxiety caused by the symptoms. MVP itself can NEVER cause high BP. Atrial flutter is a dangerous rhythm disturbance and can definitely be caused by binge drinking especially in the setting of MVP. I strongly advice you against it.   You should take Tab. Inderal 40 md 1/2 twice daily to start with and this should control all of your symptoms of MVP as well as anxiety. Inderal contains propranolol. It should be continued indefinite period of time.  Finally you need not consider yourself a heart patient, MVP is a benign common condition.   A. Madia

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Winniethepooh, A chest xray can be used to identify an accumulation of fluid in the lungs or enlargement of the heart. Fatigue may be associated with MVP. The coughing especially at night may be associated with GERD, cardiac origin etc. The Tenormin and Prilosec should lessen these symptoms. Have you been evaluated for Diabetes? Peripheral Neuropathy (numbness and tingling of the hands and feet) may be linked to diabetes. The pitting edema may be related to numerous reasons for example, congestive heart failure, kidney disorders, idiopathic (unknown causes especially in women), etc. My suggestions to you are:Inquire about a referral to a cardiologist to evaluate if the shortness of breath and pitting edema is related to a cardiac origin. Also inquire about an evaluation by an Endocrinologist to rule out any abnormalities such as hormone dysfunction, diabetes, insulin resistance, etc. I hope this information is somewhat helpful. Sincerely,

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Tricuspid valve regurgitation
content: Dear RubyMarie,  i am not sure from your history what is the cause behind the tricuspid valve regurgitation. What was your pulmonary artery pressures? What did the cardiologist tell you the reason behind the tricuspid regurgitation was?  When tricuspid regurgitation is mild or moderately severe, usually it does cause any major hemodynamic consequences, so there is no need to worry.  But if it becomes severe, it usually gives rise to symptoms and signs of right sided heart failure which are usually lower limb swelling, right sided abdominal pain (because of liver congestion), abdominal swelling because of accumulation of fluid in the abdomen, shortness of breath and indigestion. This being said however, some patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation remain asymptomatic for many years. It remains unclear why some patients tolerate this lesion and others do not.  If your cardiologist thinks it is indicated, you have to be followed by echocardiograms on regular basis and communicate any new symptom that you would develop to your cardiologist.  Treatment for tricuspid regurgitation is usually treatment of the cause if it is secondary to another disease process. If the cause needs to be surgically corrected such as valve repair or replacement, at that time, the tricuspid valve is also repaired or replaced if deemed necessary.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Complications of mitral valve repair
content: Dear AlliP,  I hope your dad is doing ok now.  After open heart surgery in general, having fluid in the lungs is not an uncommon problem.  The function of the left ventricle has to be evaluated and he needs to be started on medications according to his left ventricular function. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Rheumatoid arthritis and mvp
content: Dear wvbound83,  Rheumatoid arthritis even though it mainly affects the joints, yet it can affect other organs of the body as well. Of the organs that might be affected are the heart and the lungs. Chest pain has many causes. The ones that most doctors would like to make sure that patients don't have when they come complaining of chest pain are usually related to the heart (such as a heart attack) and to the lung if they think the symptoms might be suggestive (such as a blood clot of the lung, called pulmonary embolism).  You had a coronary angiography which is the gold standard for diagnosis of coronary disease, and from what you said, sounds like it was negative. Looks like you are wondering about having "some probable artery problem, nothing severe" and what it really means. i have not seen the results of your coronary angiogram but what this usually means is that you have very minor narrowing in your coronaries and these narrowings are so mild they can not give rise to any of the symptoms of chest pains that you have been having. These narrowings are not uncommon in patients who are at a certain age.  Besides coronary disease, rheumatoid arthritis can affect the heart in other ways that can give rise to chest pain as well such as inflammation of the membranes surrounding the heart, a condition known as pericarditis and inflammation of the muscle of the heart, a condition known as myocarditis.  Sometimes, rheumtoid arthritis will affect the small vessels of the heart (not the big coronary arteries that are seen on the angiogram) causing them to be inflammed and giving you chest pain similar to the one of heart attack.  By the way, what did the coronary angiography show regarding your mitral valve prolapse?  Chest pain can be caused by lung problems (that can be caused by rheumatoid arthritis) as well. Like the heart, if the membranes surrounding the lungs become affected by rheumatoid arthritis and inflammed, this will give rise to chest pain. Rheumatoid arthritis affects the lungs in a lot of other different manners as well. i suggest that you have a ct scan of the chest to have your lungs evaluated if not already done.  One of the causes of chest pain in any patient can be neck spine arthritis. In cases of rheumatoid arthritis, the neck spine is very frequently affected by the rheumatoid arthritis itself. So, if you were not evaluated for neck spine arthritis whether or not it is caused by rheumatoid arthritis, i suggest that you be.  The way that you described your pain, with pain to touch, makes me think that this pain might be related to affection of the skin/subcutaneous tissues (tissues underlying the skin)/muscles affection by rheumatoid arthritis.  You should be talking to your rheumatologist about these symptoms to see whether he/she thinks that these symptoms might be related to your rheumatoid arthritis and whether or not they warrant treatment with other medications such as prednisone or other newer agents.  Chest pain can be caused by acid reflux disease/heart burn or other stomach problem especially if you are taking lots of pain relievers for your arthritis.  If your blood pressure is high, it needs to be treated.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Wed Aug 10, 2005 9:37 am

author: kris8  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Apr 06, 2005 8:46 am Location: Michigan
title: Mitral valve and pregnancy
content: I am a 25 year old who was diagnosed with mild mitral regurgitation (no prolapse but thickened leaflets) and trace tricuspid regurgitation in 2/2005.  I had been having symptoms and was at the ER several times before the diagnosis.  The symptoms are somewhat under control now that I have cut out caffeine.  I still do have some palpitations and shortness of breath, especially at night.  I also suffered a bout of pericarditis in 4/2005 after a viral infection.  I am considering getting pregnant soon and wonder how this condition will affect my pregnancy.  Will the symptoms get worse?  I have read of sudden death from MR.  Also, would the pericarditis have caused the MR to worsen?  And finally, I also have allergies (seasonal) and I cannot take any of the OTC or prescription (that I have tried) medicines because it gives me tachycardia and palpitations.  Is there anything that I might be able to take?  Thanks in advance!
posted_time: Post  by kris8 » Tue Jun 14, 2005 2:46 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Mitral valve and pregnancy
content: Dear Kris8,  Usually, mitral valve regurgitation is well tolerated during pregnancy especially if the patient has good left ventricular function.  You will have to be supervised by a cardiologist during your pregnancy and you will have to be very diligent about any new symptoms that you would experience and will have to report them to your physician immediately.  After your pregnancy, you will have to be followed-up by a cardiologist and have echocardiograms on regular intervals if your cardiologist thinks it is indicated.  Pericarditis is the inflammation of the membranes surrounding the heart and i don't think it affected the mitral valve in any way.  i can not really tell you which anti-histamine medication you can take for your allergies, there are lots of them out there, i am not sure which one you tried and which one you did not, the best way is to ask the pharmacist and he/she can tell you which ones are the least notorious to cause tachycardia even though the few that i am aware of don't have tachycardia listed as one of their side effects.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
